bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, June 23, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg discusses the publication of Hench's remarks on the Cornwell painting in medical journals. The Wyeth Company will provide color inserts of the painting for publication.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, June 23, 1941
div1.opener:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
June 23, 1941
Dear Dr. Hench,
div1.p:
Your two letters and the manuscript were received last week;
also the expense sheet which I thought rather amusing as well as
very complete. Just between ourselves, I think that it exuded an
atmosphere of honesty and candor which is strangely lacking in
many expense sheets with which I have previously had intimate per-
sonal contact. You will receive a check direct from John Wyeth &
Brother within a few days.

As to the publication of your speech, our choice, of course,
would be Hygeia as it has the largest circulation. For Hygeia do
you suppose it would be possible to take out the preliminary remarks
concerning the painting and use them as an explanatory footnote?
Perhaps this sketch would have to be revised just slightly for that
purpose.

The magazine of second choice would be “Minnesota Medicine” in
which the same method of handling the introductory remarks might be
used. In any event we will be glad to provide either of the maga-
zines with a black and white halftone reproduction of the painting
as well as black and white reproductions of some of the sketches and
photographs of persons included in the painting. It might be that
the editor of one or the other of the magazines would prefer to have
small black and white halftones and have us provide a full color
printed reproduction of the painting which could be used as an in-
sert or frontispiece facing the article. It would take us almost two
months to get this insert printed and delivered to them but I doubt
if they would be using the article before that time anyway. If you
care to bring up the subject of a full color insert which we would
print and pay for you might suggest it to the editor in this manner:
For example, “I, (Dr. Hench,) believe that I can persuade John Wyeth
and Brother to supply a full colored insert if you would care to use it.”
I am sure that neither of the magazines would be willing to print
anything in full color themselves.

As to the “Annals of Medical History”, if the article were to go
to them I feel quite confident they would be willing to do quite an
elaborate job. In their July issue of this year (which I have not
seen at the moment) is scheduled a reproduction of the speeches made
at the dedication of the Osler Memorial at Philadelphia on which oc-
casion our Osler painting was unveiled, a short article on the series,
“Pioneers of American Medicine”, an article by Dean Cornwell on how
he painted the picture (incidentally I wrote this for him after pick-
ing up some of the painter's jargon) and in addition fourteen or six-
teen pages of halftones.

We are buying a considerable number of reprints from this July number. as it is From
the standpoint of getting reprints that the “Annals of Medical His-
tory” would be entirely satisfactory. It is only the wider circula-
tion of “Hygeia” and “Minnesota” Medicine" that makes those two pub-
lications appear more attractive.

As you see from the foregoing, we will be much pleased to have
you take action with any of these publications, even including the
“Bulletin of Medical Librarians Association” if indeed we come to
that. With any of these publications we will be glad to supply both
full color inserts and as many halftones of other pictures as they
wish to use. Your suggestion that Fishbein might use the photograph
of the painting with Van Etten and Lahey I think is sound. He might
use this along with a full color insert for “Hygiea” which in that
publication is something of a project as the circulation is about one
hundred thousand.

I want you to feel free to commit us to an “all-out” cooperation
with any of these journals, for the better the manner in which the job
is done the more benefit will redound to the publication and ourselves.
In all cases where the painting is reproduced we would, of course, like
a credit line in small type, “courtesy of John Wyeth and Brother”

I just received a copy of your letter to Mr. Cornwell concerning
the new photograph of Moran. I have talked with him on the 'phone and
he is going to hold the painting until the photograph arrives and make
whatever changes he thinks adviseable before the painting is delivered
to our engravers.

As to your postscript concerning our printing the speech, we will
certainly do this if none of these magazines accept it. I have a feel-
ing, however, that this will not be necessary.

I am enclosing with this letter the photographs you requested along
with a few other pictures which might be of interest to the editors of
these publications. If the material enclosed is not sufficient do not
hesitate to let me know.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, George A. Kellogg
P.S. I have not heard further from Mrs. Kissinger. I agree with you
if he is to be paralyzed as you described it would be much better for
the end to come as soon as possible. This has proved to be an unhappy
ending to our contact with him but he unquestionably enjoyed the occasion.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota.
